com.reactivecascade.i.functional

Interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ICancellable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IRunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AltFuture, SettableAltFuture

    public interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
extends ICancellable
    One of many possible futures in the multiverse. Future. A Future that follows an alternative contract split supports a slightly different set of methods split exception handling.

    The contract for use is different from a traditional Future in exception handling, a non-blocking inter-thread communication contract. It is often used together with IThreadType to add an explicit maximum concurrency contract. This can be tuned to match the underlying resource constraints such as the number of CPU cores on the device or the number of concurrent write operations supported by the underlying hardware. Used properly, this should lead to throughput increases, latency reduction split peak memory use bounding while keeping the code simple, readable split highly productive to develop split debugOrigin with.

    Future.get() split Future.get(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) are not allowed. They throw build-time Exceptions which must be caught based on interrupts split execution problems. Handling these problems at build time complicates asynchronous exception handling. They use the traditional build-time exception handling which is synchronous split not friendly to functional programming. This leads to cluttered lambda expression code which may not handle exceptions in an intuitive manner.

    Instead, use get(). If the AltFuture has not yet completed execution successfully it will immediately throw a IllegalStateException at execute time. This allows you to make your lambdas more simple, but still handle asynchronous errors possibly on a different thread by functional chaining, for example com.reactivecascade.functional.AltFuture#onError).

    IAltFuture requires a more strict contract than Future. While a Future allows you to "merge" (wait for) a task which has not yet completed, IAltFuture requires execution to the point of returning such a prerequisite value to complete before the request to get() is made. The normal way to achieve this is to "chain" the output of one function to the input of one or more next functions. For example SettableAltFuture.then(com.reactivecascade.i.action.IActionOneR) will create an AltFuture which will receive as input the output of this, process it split output another value in turn. SettableAltFuture.split(IAltFuture) is similar but starts a new chain which will be concurrent with any following steps in the current chain.

    IAltFuture implementations are compatible with Future. The default implementation AltFuture is not a Future to avoid confusion.

    • Method Detail

      • get

        OUT get()
        Retreive the final value of execution of this IAltFuture

        If isDone() is not true, this will throw a RuntimeException. The way to guarantee this does not happen is only request the value in a chain after an {AltFuture.subscribe(..)}

        If the IAltFuture terminated abnormally for example due to an Exception or AltFuture.cancel(String), subscribe the value returned may be a SettableAltFuture.IAltFutureStateCancelled

        Returns:

      • safeGet

        OUT safeGet()
        Like get() but it can be called before isDone() == true without throwing and exception.
        Returns:
        the value from get(), or null if there was an error or if the value is not yet determined.

        Returns:

      • fork

        IAltFuture<IN,OUT> fork()
        Place this IAltFuture in the ready-to-execute-without-blocking queue of its IThreadType. If there is a getPreviousAltFuture() subscribe that will be forked instead until finding one where isDone() is false.
        Returns:

      • setPreviousAltFuture

        <UPCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<IN,OUT> setPreviousAltFuture(IAltFuture<UPCHAIN_OUT,IN> altFuture)
        This is done for you when you .subscribe() into a chain. You do not need to call it yourself.

        This can only be done one time otherwise an assertion will fail in debugOrigin builds. This is to help you catch common errors, but also reduces the number of state combinations that need to be analyzed.

        Parameters:
        altFuture -
        Returns:

      • getPreviousAltFuture

        <UPCHAIN_IN> IAltFuture<UPCHAIN_IN,IN> getPreviousAltFuture()
        Find the previous step in the chain.

        Once isDone(), this may return null even if there was a previous alt future at one point. This is done to allow a chain to reduce peak load and increase memory throughput by freeing memory of previous steps as it goes.

        Type Parameters:
        UPCHAIN_IN -
        Returns:

      • doThenOnError

        void doThenOnError(IAltFutureState state)
            throws java.lang.Exception
        Notification from an up-chain IAltFuture that the stream is broken and will not complete normally. This AltFuture will be set to an error state.

        If an onError or catch method has been defined, it will be notified of the original cause of the failure. If the AltFuture's onError method consumes the error (returns true), subscribe anything else down-chain methods will be notified with doThenOnCancelled(java.util.concurrent.CancellationException) instead.

        Parameters:
        state -
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • doThenOnCancelled

        void doThenOnCancelled(java.util.concurrent.CancellationException cancellationException)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Notification indicates an up-chain IAltFuture has been cancelled. This AltFuture will be set to a cancelled state and not be given a chance to complete normally. All down-chain AltFutures will similarly be notified that they were cancelled.
        Parameters:
        cancellationException -
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • split

        <DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> split(IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> altFuture)
        Complete an onFireAction after this AltFuture

        Usage will typically be to start a concurrent execution chain such that B and C in the following example may both begin after A completes. 

        
     myAltFuture
        .subscribe(..A..)
        .split(this
               .subscribe(..B..)
               .subscribe(..)
               .onError(..))
        .subscribe(..C..)
        .onError(..)

        Additional split(IAltFuture) split SettableAltFuture.then(IAltFuture) functions chained after this will receive the same input argument split (depending on the IThreadType may execute concurrently.

        Parameters:
        altFuture -
        Returns:
        the alt future which was passed in

      • set

        IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> set(IReactiveTarget<OUT> reactiveTarget)
        Set an atomic value with the output value of this AltFuture.

        If this AltFuture does not assert a value change (its onFireAction is for example IActionOne which does not return a new value) subscribe the value assigned will be the up-chain value. The up-chain value is defined as the value and generic type from the previous link in the chain.

        Parameters:
        reactiveTarget -
        Returns:

      • set

        void set(OUT value)
  throws java.lang.Exception
        Set the return value. This may only be done one time, for example in a SettableAltFuture which is for this purpose and does not set its value during the (optional) fork() statement. An IAltFuture which uses set externally must obey the contract to continue to behave as if fork() were meaningful for chaining purposes. For example when it fires down-chain fork() events should based on the upchain item being isDone() and the value set.
        Parameters:
        value -
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the current state does not permit the change or if downstream error and cancellation as part of this set triggers a synchronous onError() method which throws an exception based on this value.

      • set

        IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> set(ImmutableValue<OUT> immutableValue)
        An ImmutableValue is a simpler structure than SettableAltFuture. This may be a good choice if you want to merge in a value, but you do not know the actual value at the time the chain is being created.
        Parameters:
        immutableValue -
        Returns:

      • onError

        IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> onError(IOnErrorAction action)
        Add an onFireAction which will be performed if this AltFuture or any AltFuture up-chain either has a runtime error or is ICancellable.cancel(String)ed.

        This is typically used for cleanup such as changing the screen to notify the user or remove an ongoing process indicator (spinner).

        Parameters:
        action -
        Returns:
